argumentText:
Define $g(z)=f(z)/z$. Then $g:\Delta\to{\mathbb{C}}$ is a holomorphic
function. The Schwarz lemma is just an application of the maximal
modulus principle to $g$.

For any $1>\epsilon>0$, by the maximal modulus principle
${\left|g\right|}$ must attain its maximum on the closed disk
$\left\{z:{\left|z\right|}\le 1-\epsilon\right\}$ at its boundary
$\left\{z:{\left|z\right|}=1-\epsilon\right\}$, say at some point
$z_{\epsilon}$. But then
${\left|g(z)\right|}\le {\left|g(z_{\epsilon})\right|} \le \frac{1}{1-\epsilon}$
for any ${\left|z\right|}\le 1-\epsilon$. Taking an infinimum as
$\epsilon\to0$, we see that values of $g$ are bounded:
${\left|g(z)\right|}\le 1$.

Thus ${\left|f(z)\right|}\le{\left|z\right|}$. Additionally,
$f'(0)=g(0)$, so we see that
${\left|f'(0)\right|}={\left|g(0)\right|}\le 1$. This is the first part
of the lemma.

Now suppose, as per the premise of the second part of the lemma, that
$|g(w)|=1$ for some $w\in\Delta$. For any $r>{\left|w\right|}$, it must
be that ${\left|g\right|}$ attains its maximal modulus (1) *inside* the
disk $\left\{z:{\left|z\right|}\le r\right\}$, and it follows that $g$
must be constant inside the entire open disk $\Delta$. So $g(z)\equiv a$
for $a=g(w)$ of modulus 1, and $f(z)=az$, as required.
